Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
WARNING: THERE IS PROFANITY USED IN THE WRITING OF THIS REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI730404189
Licensee Group Organization: House of Love Agency
Licensee Designee: Arneeshia Tamerra Brewer
Chief Administrator: Tanual Gaskew
Agency Name: House of Love Agency
Agency Address: 720 South Michigan Ave.
Saginaw, MI 48602
License Status: Original
License Expiration Date: 12/24/2023
Capacity: 8
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose

Investigation Initiation

1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms
of intervention: These include, but are not limited to, the
following:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
(i) Food or creating alternative menus.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was not offered an alternative meal option.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed on 10/05/2023 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. Youth A reported one day ground
turkey was being cooked for tacos for dinner. She stated she
does not like that meal and staff “know better” than to cook it for
dinner. Youth A stated she was not provided an alternative to that
meal. Youth A recalled dinner had not yet been served when she
left the home with law enforcement to go to the hospital, and she
ate while at the hospital sometime later that evening.
Chief Administrator was interviewed during an announced, face
to face visit at the facility on 10/26/2023. Chief Administrator
recalled she knew Youth A was struggling when Youth A stated
she wasn’t hungry and was going to refuse dinner. Chief
Administrator informed Youth A that if she did this, the Chief
Administrator would have to write up an incident report. The Chief
Administrator stated the topic of eating dinner did not come back
up until Youth A was hungry later, and she was able to eat dinner
at the hospital. The Chief Administrator did not believe dinner was
even ready to eat by the time Youth A left the facility to go to the
hospital.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 11/02/2023 over the phone. Staff 1
recalled Youth A yelling she was not going to eat dinner. Staff 1
stated she and Chief Administrator tried to talk Youth A into eating
with them, but denied Youth A ever stated that it was the specific
food being prepared that was of issue.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff there was no evidence
found Youth A was denied a meal as she left the facility prior to
dinner being served and ate at the hospital.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
2

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms
of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative
references to a youth’s background or appearance
or mental state. Yelling, threats, ridicule, or
humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A states being taunted and blamed by the Chief
Administrator.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 09/26/2023 and had no
additional information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed on 10/05/2023 during an announced,
face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated could not recall why
she was initially upset, but noted Chief Administrator was “mean”
to her and in response she wanted to “mess up” the staff office of
the facility. While in the staff only office, Youth A recalled
grabbing papers and throwing them to the ground and causing
general disarray on purpose. After doing so, Youth A recalled
hearing the Chief Administrator state “Oh no, you’re not going to
do that.” Youth A recalled Chief Administrator stating she was
going to pick up the paperwork on the ground and Youth A
intentionally stepped on them and told her “No, you’re not picking
those up, those are mine.” Youth A stated she used profane
language towards Chief Administrator while she was angry, but
Chief Administrator did not say anything profane or inappropriate
back to Youth A. With that said, Youth A stated that Chief
Administrator mouthed words to Youth A but did not audibly say
them, including “Your Dad is a cunt and your Mom is a ho.” Youth
A stated Chief Administrator touched her arm because she was
trying to get back to the office again after initially leaving. Youth A
closed the sliding door to the office and Chief Administrator put
her hands on it also to keep it closed. Youth A stated the door fell
off the track above the top of the door and she believed it had
broken. Youth A stated Chief Administrator told her she caused
the door to break, but Youth A didn’t believe that was the case.
During more escalated moments of the evening Youth A recalled
Chief Administrator telling her “If you assault me, the state is going
to have to come” to the home and “If you disrupt any of the
property, you will be arrested.” Youth A recalled both she and
3

Chief Administrator leaving the office area after that. Youth A
grabbed the visitor log from the front entrance area of the building.
Youth A was yelling and upset at that point, and could not recall
exactly what she said to Chief Administrator. Youth A stated Chief
Administrator grabbed the visitor log from Youth A, which only
made her more upset. After that all Youth A could recall was that
law enforcement came to the home and she didn't interact much
with Chief Administrator. Youth A believed there were no other
youth present during the entirety of this incident because the other
staff member working had made sure they were all staying
upstairs while Chief Administrator was with Youth A. On a
separate, previous occasion Youth A stated Chief Administrator
had used her hand to mock Youth A and make it look like her
hand was talking while Youth A was, insinuating that Chief
Administrator was not paying attention to Youth A. Youth A
believed Youth B witnessed this on one occasion but thought that
no one else ever would have because Chief Administrator was
“sneaky” when she did it. Youth A clarified Chief Administrator
never did things like this in front of anyone or out loud.
Chief Administrator was interviewed during an announced, face
to face visit at the facility on 10/26/2023. Chief Administrator
recalled Youth A was upset that afternoon. She recalled Youth A
initially escalated around dinner. Chief Administrator stated Youth
A escalated further and moved to the front of the home and
grabbed the visitor sign in book and gestured wildly with it. Chief
Administrator recalled she and Staff 1 attempted to get the book
from Youth A and Chief Administrator was able to do so without
physical contact or incident. Chief Administrator recalled Youth A
stating she was hit by Chief Administrator in doing so, but Chief
Administrator denied this occurred. Chief Administrator recalled
Youth A went into the staff office. Chief Administrator asked her
not to go in there because it was for staff only. Youth A attempted
to force her way into the sliding door. Chief Administrator was
standing next to her when Youth A slid the door open with too
much force and it came off the top track. Chief Administrator
stated her hands were not on the door at that point. She recalled
saying to Youth A “You’re damaging property and other kids have
had to leave because of that” as well as “I have to call law
enforcement now.” Chief Administrator recalled Youth A was
stating that she did not break the door, but t Chief Administrator
did, but Chief Administrator denied this was possible because she
didn’t have her hands on the door last. Youth A threw papers
around and tore them up, all from the office area. Chief
Administrator stated Youth A began to scream about “Give me my
fucking grievance,” to which Chief Administrator stated she would
4

when Youth A left the staff only office area and sat at the table to
calmly write out her grievance. Chief Administrator recalled Youth
A yelled back that she would not and moved to a different part of
the residence. Chief Administrator stated law enforcement was
called and they made it to the home shortly afterwards to continue
interaction with Youth A as she was escalated and threatened the
Chief Administrator. Chief Administrator stated there was no point
in time that she mouthed any inappropriate comments to Youth A
during this incident or on any other occasions. She also denied
mocking Youth A in any other manner. Chief Administrator stated
the only time she can recall whispering to Youth A was on a day
that she was at school with Youth A and she whispered to her that
she needed to leave school and go back to the facility, but would
be back to pick her up for the day later as normal.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 11/02/2023 over the phone. She
stated she was working with Chief Administrator the evening of
the incident. Staff 1 believed Youth A initially was upset because
she wanted to call her worker but it was the weekend and they
had told her that her worker wouldn’t be working to pick up the
phone. Staff 1 recalled Youth A yelling and cussing at her and
Chief Administrator but could not recall any specific statements.
Staff 1 stated Youth A eventually grabbed the visitor log book and
was threatening and trying to tear it up. Staff 1 believed Chief
Administrator was able to take the log book from Youth A without
incident. Staff 1 recalled Youth A going into the staff only office
area and throwing paperwork and files all over the floor. Staff 1
stated she did not see more of this part of the incident because
she was back in the kitchen to finish making dinner. Staff 1 stated
she did not see how the door to the office was broken. She did
recall hearing Chief Administrator state law enforcement had to be
called because of the broken property, and Youth A denied
breaking the door. Staff 1 stated she did not interact with Youth A
much after that point because law enforcement came and they
essentially took over interacting with Youth A. Staff 1 denied ever
hearing Chief Administrator do anything similar to mouthing
inappropriate comments to Youth A or mocking her in any form.
Attempts were made to have contact with Youth B at her
placement at a new facility on 10/18/2023, 10/23/2023,
10/24/2023, 10/26/2023 and 10/27/2023 with no success because
she declined to interview with DCWL.
Youth C, Youth D, Youth E were interviewed separately during
an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility on 11/09/2023.
None of the youth had first had knowledge of the incident in
5

question because it was before their time placed at the program.
All three youth stated they had not specifically witnessed Chief
Administrator do something like mouthing words to Youth A or any
other youth. They did not have any specific instances where it felt
Chief Administrator mocked them. Youth C noted there was a
recent instance where she felt strongly Chief Administrator was
going out of her way to accuse Youth C of not showering when
she had just left the bathroom from using the shower and did not
understand where the logic could have been to cause those
comments. Youth D stated she heard Chief Administrator say to
herself “This is why I’m not coming back here” on one recent
occasion.
Documents reviewed:
• An incident report dated 09/24/2023 authored by Staff 1
was received and reviewed. Starting at 3:45 on 09/24/2023
Youth A began to escalate because she wanted to call her
probation officer and was not able to because it was the
weekend. Youth A was described as screaming because
she believed could call her caseworkers at any time, and
then proceeded to attempt to rip up the visitor’s log. Once
the log book was taken from her, Youth A then went into
the staff-only office area and refused to leave. The incident
report stated that Youth A attempted to tear up papers in
that office and eventually “messed up” the door to the
office. It was documented that law enforcement was then
called and they came to the residence and proceeded to
interact with Youth A. It was documented that Youth A
escalated further with law enforcement, who made the
decision to have her transported to the local hospital for
medical attention.
Analysis Through interviews with youth and staff, there was no evidence
found to show that Youth A was ridiculed or derogatory language
was used towards her by Chief Administrator.
Technical Assistance provided:
• The facility should trained staff quickly on de-escalation
techniques and healthy interactions with youth. While there
was not evidence found that would produce a rule violation,
interviews with each youth placed at the program produced
examples of concerning behavior between staff and youth.
Staff appear to be struggling with power/control with youth
when not necessary. Staff are quick to utilize or reference
contacting law enforcement during situations that, with
different training or approaches from staff, may not require
6

it and may only be triggering youth escalating the situation.
Behavior management policies and house rules should be
analyzed and re-considered.
Consultation provided:
• Grievance forms should be available to youth regardless of
their current state and allow them to access that option at
any time, this may be a way to help them de-escalate in
and of itself.
• If the facility is going to use the current room as a staff only
office area it was advised the sliding door to this room have
a lock be placed on it to prevent access from youth.
• The facility utilizes security cameras but the area where the
dining room enters into the staff only office cannot be
viewed. It was advised the program explore how to capture
this area as well as any other difficult to see areas of the
building.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
11/16/2023

Tyler Armstrong Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 17, 2023
